### Notes for Class

#### Florida Crops  

* [**Guanábana**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soursop#Annona_muricata), *Annona muricata* (Annonaceae). graviola, guyabano, soursop. native to the tropical regions of the Americas and the Caribbean. 
* [**Guava**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guava), *Psidium guajava* (Myrtaceae). native to Mexico, Central America, the Caribbean and northern South America.
* [**Passion Fruit**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Passiflora_edulis), *Passiflora edulis* (Passifloraceae). native to southern Brazil through Paraguay and northern Argentina
* [**Mango**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mango), *Mangifera indica* (Anacardiaceae). believed to have originated in the region between northwestern Myanmar, Bangladesh, and northeastern India.
* [**Mamey**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pouteria_sapota), _Pouteria sapota_ (Sapotaceae). Mexico and Central America
* [**Papaya**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Papaya), _Carica papaya_ (Caricaceae). southern Mexico and Central America; also considered native to southern Florida, introduced by predecessors of the Calusa no later than 300 CE. Spaniards introduced papaya to the Old World in the 16th century. Papaya cultivation is now nearly pantropical, spanning Hawaii, central Africa, India, and Australia.
* Others: Avocado, Longan, Pitaya, Carambola/Starfruit

#### Other common fruits imported to Florida/important to Florida residents 

* [**Cashew**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cashew), _Anacardium occidentale_ (Anacardiaceae). Northeastern Brazil & Southeastern Venezuela; in 1500s distributed globally by Portuguese explorers (Goa, India ca. 1560; from there to Southeast Asia and Africa). Cashew Apple Maranon, cajuil (Puerto Rico), mereh (Venezuela), caju (Portuguese), acajou (French), mamuang himmalphan (central Thailand), jambu monet (Malay)
* [**Tamarind**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamarind), *Tamarindus indica* (Fabaceae). likely from tropical Africa
* [**Lulo**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solanum_quitoense), *Solanum quitoense* (Solanaceae). northwestern South America.
* [**Nance**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byrsonima_crassifolia), *Byrsonima crassifolia* (Malpighiaceae). maricao cimun, craboo, golden spoon, hogberry. open pine forests and grassy savannas, from central Mexico, through Central America, to Colombia, Peru, Bolivia and Brazil; it also occurs in Trinidad, Barbados, Curaçao, St. Martin, Dominica, Guadeloupe, Puerto Rico, Haiti, the Dominican Republic and throughout Cuba and the Isle of Pines. 
* [**Tamarillo**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamarillo), _Solanum betaceum_ (Solanaceae). tree tomato, tomate de árbol, tomate andino, tomate serrano, blood fruit, tomate de yuca, tomate de españa, sachatomate, berenjena, chilto and tamamoro in South America, and terong Belanda (Dutch eggplant) in Indonesia. native to the Andes of Ecuador, Colombia, Peru, Chile, Argentina and Bolivia. 
* [**Açaí**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A%C3%A7a%C3%AD_palm), _Euterpe oleraceae_ (Aracaceae). native to eastern Amazonia, especially in Brazil
